examples.title: Example 1: Declining amīcus (Masculine -us Noun)
examples.description: Complete paradigm of the standard second declension masculine noun amīcus (friend).

forms.translation: The friend is good.
The life of the friend is good. / The friend's life is good.
I give a gift to the friend.
I see the friend.
I am with the friend.
The friends are good.
The life of the friends is good. / The friends' life is good.
I give gifts to the friends.
I see the friends.
I am with the friends.

paradigm.note: Notice that amīcī appears twice (gen. sg., nom. pl.) and amīcō appears twice (dat. sg., abl. sg.) and amīcīs appears twice (dat. pl., abl. pl.). Context determines which case is meant.

examples.title: Example 2: Declining bellum (Neuter -um Noun)
examples.description: Complete paradigm demonstrating the neuter rule (nominative = accusative).

forms.translation: The war is. / There is a war.
The fortune of the war is bad.
I give a place to the war.
I see the war.
forms.neuter_note: Same form as nominative singular - THE NEUTER RULE

forms.translation: They free the land by war.
The wars are bad.
The fortune of the wars is bad.
I give an end to the wars.
I see the wars.
forms.neuter_note: Same form as nominative plural - THE NEUTER RULE

forms.translation: They free the land by wars.

paradigm.critical_note: THE NEUTER RULE: bellum (nom.) = bellum (acc.) in singular; bella (nom.) = bella (acc.) in plural. This is true for ALL neuter nouns in Latin, not just second declension!

examples.title: Example 3: -er Noun Patterns (puer vs. ager)
examples.description: Demonstrates the two different patterns for -er masculine nouns: those that keep the -e- and those that drop it.

pattern_a.translation: The boys are in the fields.

pattern_b.description: Drops the -e- in all forms except nominative singular
pattern_b.translation: The boys are in the fields.

comparison.critical_rule: You MUST memorize the genitive form to know which pattern a noun follows. The genitive shows you the stem: puerī (stem = puer-) vs. agrī (stem = agr-). There's no way to predict this from the nominative alone!

examples.title: Example 4: Mixed First and Second Declension Sentences
examples.description: Practice translating sentences that combine first declension (feminine) and second declension (masculine/neuter) nouns.

analysis.reason: Subject of the sentence (who is calling)

sentences.translation: The son gives a gift to the girl.

analysis.reason: Indirect object (to whom the gift is given)

analysis.note: Could also be nominative (neuter rule), but context shows it's the object of 'dat'

sentences.translation: The words of the girls are good. / The girls' words are good.

analysis.note: Neuter nom. pl. ends in -a, not to be confused with 1st decl. sing. -a

analysis.info: Predicate adjective (good) - agrees with verba in neuter plural

examples.title: Example 5: The Neuter Rule in Action
examples.description: Demonstrates how nominative = accusative for neuter nouns makes context critical for interpretation.

demonstrations.translation: The war is. / There is a war.
demonstrations.explanation: Bellum is nominative singular (subject). You know this because 'est' (is) needs a subject, and bellum must be nominative here.
Bellum is accusative singular (direct object). You know this because 'video' (I see) needs a direct object, and bellum must be accusative here. THE FORM IS IDENTICAL TO NOMINATIVE!
Bella is nominative plural (subject). The plural verb 'sunt' tells you bella is the subject.
Bella is accusative plural (direct object). The verb 'video' tells you bella must be the object. AGAIN, THE FORM IS IDENTICAL TO NOMINATIVE!

comparison.nominative_example: Dōna sunt bona. (The gifts are good.)
comparison.critical_point: The form 'dōna' is IDENTICAL in both sentences. Only the context (sunt vs. video) tells you whether it's nominative or accusative. This is the neuter rule in action!

examples.title: Example 6: Grammatical Gender vs. Natural Gender
examples.description: Explores how grammatical gender doesn't always match biological gender or natural properties.

cases.type: Grammatical masculine referring to objects or abstractions

examples.note: A field has no biological gender, but is grammatically masculine
Can refer to a friend of ANY gender, but the word is grammatically masculine
An abstract concept, but grammatically masculine

cases.type: First declension masculine (natural males, grammatical feminine form)

examples.note: Usually a male profession in Roman times, but uses first declension (feminine form). Gender is marked as m. to show natural gender.
Uses first declension form but refers to males
Uses first declension form but refers to males

examples.key_principle: You CANNOT predict a noun's grammatical gender from its meaning. You must memorize the gender as part of the vocabulary: amīcus, amīcī, M. (not just 'friend' but 'friend, masculine')

examples.title: Example 7: Form Identification Practice
examples.description: Quick drills to test recognition of second declension forms.

drills.question: What case(s) could 'amīcī' be?
drills.explanation: Context tells them apart: 'Vita amīcī' (gen. sg.) vs. 'Amīcī sunt' (nom. pl.)

drills.question: If you see 'bellōrum' in a sentence, what case must it be?
drills.explanation: The ending -ōrum is unique to genitive plural. Translation: 'of the wars'

drills.question: What's the difference between 'puerum' and 'puerōs'?
drills.answer: puerum = accusative singular (the boy, as object); puerōs = accusative plural (the boys, as object)
drills.explanation: Both are accusative (direct objects), but -um is singular, -ōs is plural

drills.question: Why is 'bella' ambiguous?
drills.answer: It could be nominative plural OR accusative plural (neuter rule: nom. = acc.)
drills.explanation: Context determines: 'Bella sunt' (nom. pl. subject) vs. 'Bella video' (acc. pl. object)

drills.question: How do you know if an -er noun keeps the -e- or drops it?
drills.explanation: puer, puerī → keeps -e- (stem = puer-); ager, agrī → drops -e- (stem = agr-)

drills.question: What case is 'amīcō'?
drills.explanation: Context shows which: 'Amīcō dōnum do' (dat. = to the friend) vs. 'Cum amīcō sum' (abl. = with the friend)

drills.question: Is 'dōna' first declension or second declension?
drills.explanation: From dōnum, dōnī, n. The plural nom/acc is 'dōna' (looks like 1st decl. but it's 2nd decl. neuter)
